english.context: The random variables X and Y denote the coordinates of a point that is uniformly distributed on the disk D = {(x,y)∈ℝ²∣x²+y²≤1}.
english.question: The probability P(Y > X + 1) is determined to be

explanation: Uniform on the unit disk ⇒ probability equals area ratio. Rotate by 45°: u=(y−x)/√2, v=(x+y)/√2. The unit disk is u²+v²≤1 and the line y=x+1 becomes u=1/√2, so we need the circular cap u>1/√2. Its area is A=2∫_{1/√2}^1 √(1−u²) du = [u√(1−u²)+arcsin u]_{1/√2}^1 = π/4−1/2. Divide by total area π to get P = (π/4−1/2)/π = 1/4 − 1/(2π).
explanation_key_steps: Use rotational invariance; set u=(y−x)/√2 so y>x+1 ⇔ u>1/√2
Compute cap area inside u²+v²≤1 for u>1/√2: A=2∫_{1/√2}^1 √(1−u²) du
Evaluate to A=π/4−1/2 and divide by π
explanation_pitfalls: Forgetting to divide the cap area by π
Choosing the wrong side of the line y=x+1

danish.context: Tre personer A, B og C mistænkes i forbindelse med en forbrydelse. Indledningsvist tildeler politiet de subjektive sandsynligheder 0, 9, 0, 09 og 0,01 for, at A henholdsvis B og C er den skyldige. For at støtte bevisførelsen vil man benytte en politihund, der med en vis sandsynlighed kan knytte forbindelse mellem en genstand fundet på gerningsstedet og en mistænkt. Man regner med, at hvis A henholdsvis B og C er skyldige, er der en sandsynlighed på 0,95 for, at hunden vil pege på denne, medens der er en sandsynlighed på 0,025 for, at hunden vil pege på en af de to andre. Denne sidste oplysning kan angives ved de følgende betingede sandsynligheder $$\begin{aligned} & \mathrm{P}(\text { Hund angiver } A \mid A \text { er gerningspersonen })=0,950 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Hund angiver } B \mid A \text { er gerningspersonen })=0,025 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Hund angiver } C \mid A \text { er gerningspersonen })=0,025 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Hund angiver } B \mid B \text { er gerningspersonen })=0,950 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Hund angiver } A \mid B \text { er gerningspersonen })=0,025 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Hund angiver } C \mid B \text { er gerningspersonen })=0,025 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Hund angiver } C \mid C \text { er gerningspersonen })=0,950 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Hund angiver } A \mid C \text { er gerningspersonen })=0,025 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Hund angiver } B \mid C \text { er gerningspersonen })=0,025 \end{aligned}$$ Man lader nu hunden angive en person. Det viser sig, at hunden angiver C.
danish.question: Hvilken sandsynlighed bør politiet nu lægge til grund for, at C rent faktisk er den skyldige

english.context: Three people A, B, and C are suspected in connection with a crime. Initially, the police assign the subjective probabilities 0, 9, 0, 09 and 0,01 that A, B, and C respectively are the guilty party. To support the evidence, they will use a police dog that, with some probability, can link an object found at the crime scene to a suspect. It is assumed that if A, B, or C is guilty, there is a probability of 0,95 that the dog will point to that person, while there is a probability of 0,025 that the dog will point to one of the other two. This latter information can be given by the following conditional probabilities $$\begin{aligned} & \mathrm{P}(\text { Dog indicates } A \mid A \text { is the perpetrator })=0,950 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Dog indicates } B \mid A \text { is the perpetrator })=0,025 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Dog indicates } C \mid A \text { is the perpetrator })=0,025 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Dog indicates } B \mid B \text { is the perpetrator })=0,950 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Dog indicates } A \mid B \text { is the perpetrator })=0,025 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Dog indicates } C \mid B \text { is the perpetrator })=0,025 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Dog indicates } C \mid C \text { is the perpetrator })=0,950 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Dog indicates } A \mid C \text { is the perpetrator })=0,025 \\ & \mathrm{P}(\text { Dog indicates } B \mid C \text { is the perpetrator })=0,025 \end{aligned}$$ The dog is now allowed to indicate a person. It turns out that the dog indicates C.
english.question: What probability should the police now assign to C actually being the guilty party?

explanation: Use Bayes’ theorem with priors P(A)=0.90, P(B)=0.09, P(C)=0.01 and dog-indication probabilities. Let D_C be “dog indicates C.” Compute P(D_C) by total probability, then P(C|D_C).
explanation_pitfalls: Equating the dog’s 95% indication rate with the posterior.
Ignoring the high prior on A when computing P(D_C).

danish.context: De stokastiske variable ( V, W ) er bivariat normalfordelt med V ∈ normal (1, 4), W ∈ normal (2, 9) og korrelationskoefficient $\rho=-\frac{1}{4}$.
danish.question: Man finder P(V - W ≤ 0) til

english.context: The random variables (V, W) are bivariate normally distributed with V ~ Normal(1, 4), W ~ Normal(2, 9) and correlation coefficient $\rho=-\frac{1}{4}$.
english.question: We find P(V - W ≤ 0) to be

explanation: Since (V,W) are jointly normal, U=V−W is normal with mean μ_U=μ_V−μ_W=1−2=−1 and variance Var(U)=Var(V)+Var(W)−2Cov(V,W). With σ_V=2, σ_W=3, ρ=−1/4 ⇒ Cov(V,W)=ρσ_Vσ_W=(−1/4)·2·3=−3/2. Hence Var(U)=4+9−2(−3/2)=16, so U~N(−1,16). Therefore P(V−W≤0)=P(U≤0)=Φ((0−(−1))/4)=Φ(1/4).
explanation_pitfalls: Dropping the −2Cov term in Var(V−W).
Sign error from negative ρ when computing covariance.
Confusing V−W with W−V.

danish.context: Lad den simultane tæthed af de stokastiske variable X og Y være givet ved $$f(x, y)= \begin{cases}2, & \text { for } 0<x<y<1 \\ 0, & \text { ellers }\end{cases}$$ Man danner nu en ny stokastisk variabel $Z=\frac{Y}{X}$ med tæthedsfunktion f_(Z)(z).
danish.question: Indenfor værdimængden af Z findes f_(Z)(z) til

english.context: Let the joint density of the random variables X and Y be given by $$f(x, y)= \begin{cases}2, & \text { for } 0<x<y<1 \\ 0, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}$$ We now form a new random variable $Z=\frac{Y}{X}$ with density function f_(Z)(z).
english.question: Within the value range of Z, f_(Z)(z) is found to be

knowledge_points: Uniform distribution on a triangular region
explanation: Support: 0 < x < y < 1 implies Z = Y/X ≥ 1. Use transformation (x,z) with y = zx. Jacobian |∂(x,y)/∂(x,z)| = x. Then f_{X,Z}(x,z) = f_{X,Y}(x,zx)|J| = 2x for 0 < x < 1/z, z ≥ 1. Hence f_Z(z) = ∫_0^{1/z} 2x dx = 1/z^2 for z ≥ 1 (0 otherwise).
explanation_key_steps: Identify support: z ≥ 1 from 0 < x < y
Set y = zx; compute Jacobian |J| = x
explanation_pitfalls: Forgetting support z ≥ 1
Using wrong Jacobian (it is x, not 1/x)
Incorrect upper limit for x (it is 1/z)

danish.context: En forretningsrejsende skal nå en flyafgang og overvejer, om der er tid til at gå på restaurant inden rejsen. Vedkommende skønner, at der er en sandsynlighed på $\frac{4}{5}$ for at finde en passende restaurant, medens der er en sandsynlighed på $\frac{1}{2}$ for, at den rejsende kan nå at få serveret og indtage sit måltid givet, at den forretningsrejsende har fundet en passende restaurant.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at den forretningsrejsende kan nå at finde en passende restaurant og indtage et måltid inden flyrejsen, er   ---- ----------------

english.context: A business traveler needs to catch a flight and is considering whether there is time to go to a restaurant before the trip. They estimate that there is a probability of $\frac{4}{5}$ of finding a suitable restaurant, while there is a probability of $\frac{1}{2}$ that the traveler has time to be served and eat their meal, given that the business traveler has found a suitable restaurant.
english.question: The probability that the business traveler has time to find a suitable restaurant and have a meal before the flight is   ---- ----------------

explanation: Let A = find a suitable restaurant, P(A)=4/5. Let B = have time to eat, with P(B|A)=1/2. Then P(A∩B)=P(A)P(B|A)=(4/5)(1/2)=2/5.
explanation_pitfalls: Use the conditional probability P(B|A), not P(B) unconditionally

danish.context: En kontinuert stokastisk variabel X har en tæthed f(x) som angivet på figuren. [image]
danish.question: Fordelingsfunktionen F(x) for X er

english.context: A continuous random variable X has a density f(x) as shown in the figure. [image]
english.question: The cumulative distribution function F(x) for X is

explanation:
From the figure, f(x) is trapezoidal on [−2,2]: it rises linearly from 0 to 1/3 on [−2,−1], is flat at 1/3 on [−1,1], and falls linearly to 0 on [1,2] (0 otherwise). Integrating f from −2 to x gives:
- For −2≤x<−1: F(x)=∫_{−2}^{x}(t+2)/3 dt=(x+2)^2/6.
- For −1≤x<1: F(x)=F(−1)+∫_{−1}^{x}(1/3) dt=1/6+(x+1)/3=(2x+3)/6.
- For 1≤x≤2: F(x)=1−∫_{x}^{2}(2−t)/3 dt=1−(x−2)^2/6=(6−(x−2)^2)/6.
This matches option 1 and satisfies F(−2)=0, F(2)=1, and monotonicity/continuity.
explanation_key_steps: Identify trapezoidal pdf from the figure (linear up, flat, linear down).
Integrate piecewise from −2 to x to obtain F(x).
Verify F(−2)=0, F(2)=1, and continuity at −1 and 1.
explanation_pitfalls: A valid CDF must be nondecreasing and reach 1 at x=2; reject forms that are flat where the pdf is positive or that decrease.

danish.context: I et kommunikationsnetværk deles meddelelser op i mindre brudstykker af information i såkaldte pakker. Overførselstiden af en enkelt pakke kan med god tilnærmelse beskrives ved brug af en eksponentialfordelt stokastisk variabel med middelværdi 1, 5 ms. Umiddelbart efter, at en pakke er modtaget succesfyldt, startes transmissionen af den næste pakke. Overførselstiderne kan anses for uafhængige. En given meddelelse er af en sådan størrelse, at den deles op i 4 pakker.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at hele meddelelsen er overført indenfor 8 ms , bestemmes til

english.context: In a communications network, messages are divided into smaller fragments of information in so-called packets. The transmission time of a single packet can, to a good approximation, be described using an exponentially distributed random variable with mean 1.5 ms. Immediately after a packet has been successfully received, transmission of the next packet is started. The transmission times can be regarded as independent. A given message is of such a size that it is divided into 4 packets.
english.question: The probability that the entire message is transmitted within 8 ms is determined to be

explanation: Each packet time Xi ~ Exp(λ) with mean 1/λ = 1.5 ms ⇒ λ = 2/3 ms⁻¹. The total time S4 = X1+X2+X3+X4 is Erlang/Gamma with shape k=4 and rate λ. Its CDF is P(Sk ≤ t) = 1 − e^{−λt} ∑_{i=0}^{k−1} (λt)^i/i!. With t=8 ms, λt = (2/3)·8 = 16/3, so P(S4 ≤ 8) = 1 − e^{−16/3} ∑_{i=0}^{3} (16/3)^i/i!, which matches option 2.
explanation_key_steps: Sum of 4 iid exponentials ⇒ Erlang/Gamma(k=4, rate λ).
Plug t = 8 → λt = 16/3 to get the expression.
explanation_pitfalls: Confusing mean with rate (λ = 1/mean).
Missing the complement term in the Erlang CDF (the 1 − …).
Using a normal approximation unnecessarily.

danish.context: Vi betragter Y, der er maksimum af 4 uafhængige uniform (0, 1) variable og X, der er minimum af de samme 4 uniform (0, 1) variable.
danish.question: Den simultane fordelingsfunktion F(x, y) findes til

english.context: We consider Y, which is the maximum of 4 independent uniform (0, 1) variables and X, which is the minimum of the same 4 uniform (0, 1) variables.
english.question: The joint distribution function F(x, y) is found to be

explanation:
Let X=min(U1,…,U4) and Y=max(U1,…,U4) with Ui iid Uniform(0,1). For 0≤x≤y≤1,
F(x,y)=P(X≤x,Y≤y)=P(all Ui≤y)−P(all Ui∈(x,y])=y^4−(y−x)^4.
If y<x then F(x,y)=0; standard boundary cases follow by continuity.
explanation_key_steps: Express {X≤x,Y≤y} as {all Ui≤y} minus {all Ui in (x,y]}.
explanation_pitfalls: Forgetting the constraint 0≤x≤y≤1.
Treating X and Y as independent.
Using power 3 instead of 4 (there are four variables).

danish.context: En del danskere har for lave niveauer af D-vitamin, så det kan være klinisk relevant at overvåge niveauet løbende. På en passende normeret skala kan man med rimelighed beskrive to på hinanden følgende målinger af D -vitamin på den samme person ved en standardiseret bivariat normalfordeling med korrelationskoefficient $\frac{4}{5}$. En person får nu målt sit niveau af D-vitamin til at være under gennemsnittet. Ved den efterfølgende måling er man interesseret i at undersøge, om denne måling er endnu lavere end den først betragtede.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at den næste måling, der tages, er mindre end den først tagne, findes til

english.context: Some Danes have too low levels of vitamin D, so it can be clinically relevant to monitor the level continuously. On a suitably normalized scale, two consecutive measurements of vitamin D on the same person can reasonably be described by a standardized bivariate normal distribution with correlation coefficient $\frac{4}{5}$. A person now has their vitamin D level measured to be below the mean. At the subsequent measurement, we are interested in examining whether this measurement is even lower than the first one considered.
english.question: The probability that the next measurement taken is less than the first one taken is found to be

explanation:
Let (X,Y) be standard bivariate normal with Corr(X,Y)=ρ=4/5. Rotate to U=(X+Y)/√2 and V=(Y−X)/√2, which are independent with Var(U)=1+ρ and Var(V)=1−ρ. We need P(Y<X | X<0). Note Y<X ⇔ V<0 and X<0 ⇔ U−V<0. Hence
P(Y<X | X<0)=P(V<0, U−V<0)/P(U−V<0).
Since U and V are independent, U−V ~ N(0,2), so P(U−V<0)=1/2. For W1=V, W2=U−V, Corr(W1,W2)=−√((1−ρ)/2)=−1/√10. For zero-mean bivariate normal, P(W1<0,W2<0)=1/4+(1/(2π))arcsin(r). Thus
P(Y<X | X<0)=2[1/4−(1/(2π))arcsin(1/√10)]=1/2−(1/π)arcsin(1/√10)=1/2−Arctan(1/3)/π.
explanation_key_steps: Translate events: Y<X ⇔ V<0; X<0 ⇔ U−V<0.
explanation_pitfalls: Ignoring the conditioning and computing P(Y<X)=1/2.
Using Corr(X,Y) directly in the orthant formula instead of Corr(V,U−V).
Missing the arcsin–arctan identity arcsin(1/√10)=arctan(1/3).

danish.context: En retfærdig mønt kastes indtil, der opnås krone, eller indtil, at der er kastet i alt fire kast.
danish.question: Det forventede antal møntkast er

english.context: A fair coin is tossed until a head is obtained, or until a total of four tosses have been made.
english.question: The expected number of coin tosses is

explanation: Let T be the number of tosses until the first head. For a fair coin, T ~ Geom(p=1/2), so E[T] = 1/p = 2. Equivalently, by the tail-sum formula, E[T] = Σ_{k≥1} P(T ≥ k) = Σ_{k≥1} (1/2)^{k-1} = 2.
explanation_key_steps: Model the number of tosses until first head as T ~ Geom(1/2).
explanation_pitfalls: Do not mix with the truncated-at-4 version; that expectation would be 15/8.

danish.context: En person har 15 mønter i sin lomme fordelt som 5 1-krones mønter, 5 50-øres mønter og 5 25 -øres mønter. Personen skal betale 1, 75kr. for et stykke tyggegummi og griber tilfældigt 3 mønter i lommen. Det antages, at personen ikke er i stand til at skelne mellem mønterne med hånden.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at personen præcist har udtaget det rette beløb, findes til

english.context: A person has 15 coins in their pocket distributed as 5 1-kroner coins, 5 50-øre coins, and 5 25-øre coins. The person has to pay 1.75 kr for a piece of chewing gum and randomly grabs 3 coins from the pocket. It is assumed that the person is not able to distinguish between the coins by touch.
english.question: The probability that the person has picked exactly the correct amount is

explanation: Let a,b,c be counts of 1-kr, 50-øre, 25-øre coins among the 3 drawn. Then a+b+c=3 and 100a+50b+25c=175 ⇒ 4a+2b+c=7 ⇒ 3a+b=4. The only nonnegative integer solution is (a,b,c)=(1,1,1). Favorable draws = 5·5·5=125; total draws = C(15,3)=455. Probability = 125/455 = 25/91.
explanation_pitfalls: Using ordered draws instead of combinations (result is the same but complicates counting)
Assuming multiple denomination combinations sum to 1.75 kr
Treating identical denominations as indistinguishable in counting selections

danish.context: Man har $\mathrm{P}(X=x, Y=y)=\frac{3!}{x!y!(3-x-y)!}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{x}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{y}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3-x-y}$, hvor X og Y begge er ikkenegative heltal med X + Y ≤ 3. Man ønsker at bestemme sandsynlighederne P(X = x ∣ Y = 1) for alle værdier, hvor sandsynligheden er større end 0.
danish.question: Man finder

english.context: One has $\mathrm{P}(X=x, Y=y)=\frac{3!}{x!y!(3-x-y)!}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{x}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{y}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3-x-y}$, where X and Y are both nonnegative integers with X + Y ≤ 3. One wishes to determine the probabilities P(X = x ∣ Y = 1) for all values for which the probability is greater than 0.
english.question: One finds

explanation: Treat (X,Y,Z) as multinomial with n=3 and category probabilities (1/2, 1/4, 1/4). Conditioning on Y=1 leaves n=2 trials allocated between X and Z with normalized probabilities p_X = (1/2)/(1/2+1/4)=2/3 and p_Z=1/3. Thus X|Y=1 ~ Binomial(2, 2/3), giving P(X=0|Y=1)=(1/3)^2=1/9, P(X=1|Y=1)=2(2/3)(1/3)=4/9, P(X=2|Y=1)=(2/3)^2=4/9.
explanation_key_steps: Condition on Y=1 ⇒ remaining 2 trials split between X and Z with normalized probs 2/3 and 1/3.
Use Binomial(2, 2/3) to compute P(X=x | Y=1) for x=0,1,2.
explanation_pitfalls: Forgetting to renormalize between X and the non-(X,Y) category when conditioning on Y=1.
Including x=3, which violates x+y\le 3 when y=1.

danish.context: De stokastiske variable ( X, Y ) er uafhængige og identisk fordelte med Var (X) = Var (Y) = 8.
danish.question: Om sandsynligheden for, at den numeriske afvigelse mellem X og Y er mindst 20, gælder
options: Der er ikke tilstrækkeligt med oplysninger til, at man kan udtale sig om sandsynligheden

english.context: The random variables (X, Y) are independent and identically distributed with Var(X) = Var(Y) = 8.
english.question: Regarding the probability that the absolute deviation between X and Y is at least 20, it holds that
options: There is not sufficient information to say anything about the probability

explanation:
Let Z = X − Y. For i.i.d. Normal X, Y with Var(X) = Var(Y) = 8, we have Z ~ N(0, Var(X)+Var(Y)) = N(0,16). Therefore,
P(|X−Y| ≥ 20) = 2 Φ(−20/4) = 2 Φ(−5).
explanation_key_steps: Define Z = X − Y and compute Var(Z) = 8 + 8 = 16, E[Z]=0
Use closure of independent Normals: Z ~ N(0,16)
explanation_pitfalls: Using Chebyshev only yields a loose upper bound 1/25, not the exact value
Miscomputing the SD of X−Y (it is 4, not √8 or 8)

danish.context: Betragt et polært koordinatsystem med et bombemål placeret i centrum. Et bombefly kaster en bombe, der rammer afstanden R fra centrum med tætheden $f_{R}(r)=r e^{-\frac{1}{2} r^{2}}$. Sandsynligheden for, at bombemålet bliver ødelagt, er e^( - r²), givet bomben rammer afstanden r fra centrum.
danish.question: Hvad er sandsynligheden for, at bombemålet bliver ødelagt?

english.context: Consider a polar coordinate system with a bombing target at the origin. A bomber throws a bomb hitting a distance R from the origin with the density $f_{R}(r)=r e^{-\frac{1}{2} r^{2}}$. The probability that the target will be destroyed is e^( - r²) if the bomb hits at a distance r from the origin.
english.question: What is the probability that the bombing target will be destroyed?

explanation: We need the unconditional probability: E[e^{-R^2}]. With R ~ Rayleigh(σ=1), Y=R^2 ~ Exp(rate=1/2). Then E[e^{-Y}] = (1/2)/(1/2+1) = 1/3. Hence, the target is destroyed with probability 1/3.
explanation_key_steps: Use law of total expectation: P(destroy) = E[e^{-R^2}].
Compute E[e^{-Y}] via Laplace transform: λ/(λ+1) with λ=1/2.
explanation_pitfalls: Mixing up the Rayleigh scale parameter.
Forgetting that R≥0 or mishandling the exponent combination.

danish.context: En svømmeforening har en basistrup bestående af 18 svømmere. Heraf er 2 bedst til rygcrawl, 7 bedst til brystcrawl, 5 bedst til butterfly og 4 bedst til medley. Til en holdstafet udtages 4 af de 18 svømmere tilfældigt.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at der er netop 2, der er bedst til butterfly, blandt de 4, er

english.context: A swimming club has 18 swimmers. Two of those are backstroke specialists, 7 are crawl specialists, 5 are butterfly specialist, and 4 are medley specialists. Four swimmers are selected randomly for a relay event.
english.question: The probability that there are exactly two butterfly specialist among the four is

explanation: We sample 4 without replacement from 18 swimmers, with 5 butterfly (successes) and 13 non-butterfly. The count of butterfly specialists follows a hypergeometric distribution. The probability of exactly 2 butterfly specialists is C(5,2)·C(13,2) / C(18,4).
explanation_key_steps: Model as hypergeometric: N=18, K=5 (butterfly), n=4 draws
explanation_pitfalls: Using with-replacement/binomial model like (5/18)^2(13/18)^2
Sequential multiplication without accounting for combinations/order

danish.context: Et materiale udsender partikler, således at tiderne mellem partiklerne kan beskrives ved uafhængige og eksponentialfordelte stokastiske variable med en middelværdi på 2 minutter.
danish.question: Hvad er sandsynligheden for, at den tredje partikel udsendes netop mellem 3 og 4 minutter efter, at registrering er påbegyndt?

english.context: A material emits particles, such that the time between particle emissions can be described by independent exponentially distributed random variables with a mean of 2 minutes.
english.question: The probability that the third particle is emitted exactly between the third and fourth minute after the start of registration is

explanation: Interarrival times are Exp(λ=1/2). The third arrival time T3 ~ Gamma(k=3, rate=1/2). Thus P(3 < T3 < 4) = F(4) − F(3), where for k=3: F(t) = 1 − e^{−λ t}(1 + λ t + (λ t)^2/2). With λ=1/2, this gives (29/8) e^{−3/2} − 5 e^{−2}.
explanation_key_steps: Model as Poisson process with rate λ=1/2.
Compute F(4)−F(3) with F(t)=1−e^{−λ t}(1+λ t+(λ t)^2/2).
explanation_pitfalls: Do not require exactly two events by t=3; T3∈(3,4) also allows 0 or 1 event by t=3.

danish.context: Idet X₁ og X₂ er to uafhængige eksponentialfordelte variable danner man X = min (X₁,X₂) og Y = max (X₁,X₂) med simultan tæthedsfunktion f(x, y) = 2λ²e^( - λ(x + y)).
danish.question: Tæthedsfunktionen f_(Z)(z) for $Z=\frac{X}{Y}$ findes til

english.question: The density f_(Z)(z) of $Z=\frac{X}{Y}$ is

explanation: X ~ Unif(-1/2, 1/2) so f_X(x)=1 on [-1/2,1/2]. Let Y=X^2, so support is y∈[0,1/4]. For y∈(0,1/4), preimages are x=±√y (both in the interval) and g'(x)=2x. Thus f_Y(y)=∑ f_X(x_i)/|g'(x_i)|=1/(2√y)+1/(2√y)=1/√y. Outside [0,1/4], f_Y(y)=0. (The singularity at 0 is integrable.)

Obtain f_Y(y)=1/√y on (0,1/4], 0 otherwise; integrates to 1.

explanation: Let D = X − Y. Since (X,Y) is bivariate normal, D is normal with mean μ_D = μ_X − μ_Y = 1 − 2 = −1 and variance Var(D) = Var(X)+Var(Y)−2Cov(X,Y). With σ_X=2, σ_Y=3, ρ=−1/4 ⇒ Cov(X,Y)=ρσ_Xσ_Y=(−1/4)(2)(3)=−3/2. Hence Var(D)=4+9−2(−3/2)=16, so σ_D=4. Therefore P(X−Y ≤ 0)=P(D ≤ 0)=Φ((0−(−1))/4)=Φ(1/4).

explanation_pitfalls: Use −2Cov(X,Y) for Var(X−Y).
Account for μ_D being −1.
Correlation affects variance via covariance.

english.question: P(H) can be expressed alternatively as
options: It is not possible to express P(H) using N with the information given.

explanation:
Let F_i = {N = i}. The events F_0, F_1, F_2 are disjoint, so by additivity:
P(H) = P(F_0 ∪ F_1 ∪ F_2) = Σ_{i=0}^2 P(F_i) = Σ_{i=0}^2 P(N=i) = e^{-γ}(1+γ+γ^2/2).
explanation_key_steps: Use disjoint-union additivity: P(⋃ F_i) = Σ P(F_i).
Plug in Poisson probabilities for i=0,1,2.
explanation_pitfalls: P(N=0, N=1, N=2) is an intersection and equals 0, not the desired union.
P(N₀) etc. should be read as P(N=0), not as a new random variable.
P(F_(i)≤2) is not a meaningful event.

explanation: Let N ~ Poisson(μ). Given N, the number of female larvae F | N ~ Binomial(N, p), so E[F | N] = Np. By the law of total expectation, E[F] = E[Np] = pE[N] = μp. (Equivalently, thinning: F ~ Poisson(μp), mean μp.)

english.context: In a physical experiment, electrons are emitted at high velocity towards a screen. Here the screen can be considered to be of infinite size. The electrons are emitted towards a specific point on the screen. Due to randomness the electrons do not hit this point precisely. The hitting point of an electron on the screen can be described by the coordinates ( X, Y ), where X and Y are independent standard normal random variables. It is of special interest to know whether the electrons hit between one and two length units from the target (the origin of the coordinate system).
english.question: The probability that an electron hits between 1 and 2 length units from the target is

explanation: Let R = √(X² + Y²). With X, Y ~ N(0,1) iid, R has a Rayleigh(σ=1) distribution, whose CDF is F_R(r) = 1 − exp(−r²/2) for r ≥ 0. Thus P(1 ≤ R ≤ 2) = F_R(2) − F_R(1) = (1 − e^{−2}) − (1 − e^{−1/2}) = e^{−1/2} − e^{−2}. Equivalently, R² ~ χ²(2), yielding the same result.
explanation_pitfalls: Using the univariate normal CDF Φ instead of the Rayleigh CDF
Forgetting the radial Jacobian factor r in polar coordinates
Confusing with a Poisson-tail form

danish.context: Levetiden af en elektronisk komponent kan med god tilnærmelse beskrives ved en eksponential( λ ) fordelt stokastisk variabel. Man ved, at komponenten har opnået alderen t.
danish.question: Under de givne oplysninger, hvad er da sandsynligheden for, at komponenten fejler netop i intervallet [t, t + dt]. Svaret kan eventuelt angives approksimativt

english.context: The life time of an electronic component can with reasonable accuracy be described by an exponential( λ ) random variable. The component has reached the age t.
english.question: With the given information, determine the probability that the component will fail in the interval [t, t + dt]. The answer can possibly be given only approximatively.

explanation:
Let T ~ Exp(λ) with pdf f_T(t)=λe^{-λt}. The (unconditional) probability of failure in a small interval [t, t+dt] is approximated by the pdf at t times dt:
P(T ∈ [t, t+dt]) ≈ f_T(t) dt = λe^{-λt} dt.
explanation_key_steps: Apply small-interval approximation: P([t,t+dt]) ≈ f_T(t) dt.
explanation_formulae: Exact: P(T∈[t,t+dt]) = e^{-λt} - e^{-λ(t+dt)} ≈ λe^{-λt} dt
explanation_pitfalls: Mixing unconditional probability with the conditional (given survival to t), which would be ≈ λ dt due to memorylessness.
Forgetting that the exact small-interval probability is e^{-λt} - e^{-λ(t+dt)}, which reduces to λe^{-λt} dt for small dt.

explanation: After setting aside v sixes, you roll the remaining 6−v dice once. To reach a total of w sixes, you need exactly w−v sixes on the second roll. Thus, for v ≤ w ≤ 6 the probability is Binomial(6−v, w−v) with p = 1/6; otherwise it is 0. Since no option states this piecewise condition explicitly, the only consistent choice is “Do not know.”

Require k = w − v successes on the second roll.
Account for bounds: probability is 0 if w < v or w > 6.
No option includes the necessary piecewise definition.

Accepting a non-piecewise expression that implies nonzero probability for impossible w.

english.question: The probability that the absolute value of the slope of the line is less than 1 is

explanation: Let the center be the origin and write the random point in polar coordinates (R, θ). For a point chosen uniformly in the disk, θ is uniform on [0, 2π). The line through the center and the point has slope m = tan θ (vertical cases have measure 0). We need P(|m| < 1) = P(|tan θ| < 1). Since tan has period π, |tan θ| < 1 ⇔ θ mod π ∈ (-π/4, π/4), an interval of length π/2 per period π. Thus the probability is (π/2)/π = 1/2.
explanation_key_steps: Parametrize by polar angle θ, which is uniform.
Slope m = tan θ; vertical events have probability 0.
|tan θ| < 1 holds on length π/2 in each period π.
explanation_pitfalls: Worrying about undefined slope at vertical lines; they occur with probability 0.
Including the radial coordinate; only the angle matters.

If a human error occurs, then the probability that an air-crash occurs $\frac{1}{10000}$, while the probability, that an air-crash occurs at the occurrence of a mechanical failure is $\frac{1}{1000}$, and finally the probability that an air-crash occurs in the event of an act of terrorism is $\frac{2}{3}$. explanation:
Let X1,…,X5 ~ i.i.d. Exp(μ) with F(x)=1−e^{−μx}, f(x)=μe^{−μx}, x≥0. The second largest is the 4th order statistic X_(4). For order statistics:

f_{X_(k)}(x) = [n! / ((k−1)!(n−k)!)] [F(x)]^{k−1} [1−F(x)]^{n−k} f(x).

With n=5, k=4:

f_{X_(4)}(x)=20 μ e^{−2 μ x} [1−e^{−μ x}]^3 = 20μ(e^{−2μx} − 3e^{−3μx} + 3e^{−4μx} − e^{−5μx}), x≥0.

Apply the general pdf formula for the k-th order statistic
Plug F(x)=1−e^{−μx} and f(x)=μe^{−μx} and simplify/expand
explanation_pitfalls: Confusing second largest with second smallest (use k=4, not k=2)
Treating μ as a mean instead of a rate

The catch of each species by a random trawl haul can be described with reasonable accuracy by a normal distribution with mean 10 ton (sandeels) and 1 ton (herring) and standard deviation 2 ton (sandeels) and 0.3 ton (herring). The joint distribution can be assumed to be bivariate normal with correlation coefficient 0.7. In a trawl haul one obtained 14 ton of sandeels.

explanation:
Let X (sandeels) ~ N(μ_X=10, σ_X=2) and Y (herring) ~ N(μ_Y=1, σ_Y=0.35) with corr ρ=0.7. For a bivariate normal, the conditional mean is:
E[Y | X=x] = μ_Y + ρ (σ_Y/σ_X) (x − μ_X).
With x=14: ρ(σ_Y/σ_X) = 0.7*(0.35/2) = 0.1225, so E[Y|X=14] = 1 + 0.1225*4 = 1.49 ton.
explanation_key_steps: Use bivariate normal conditional expectation formula.
explanation_pitfalls: Do not use the unconditional mean of Y; condition on X via the bivariate normal formula.
Do not invert the σ ratio; it is σ_Y/σ_X.

The density of the chosen point's coordinates is therefore given by f(x, y) = c for $(x, y) \in\left\{|x| \leq \frac{1}{2} \wedge|y| \leq \frac{1}{2}\right\} \backslash\left\{|x| \leq \frac{1}{4} \wedge|y| \leq \frac{1}{4}\right\}$ and 0 otherwise, where \ denotes set difference, i.e., the points that are in the former set without being in the latter.

explanation: Since the pdf is constant on the region R (outer square minus inner square), it must satisfy c · Area(R) = 1. The outer square has side 1 (area 1), the inner square has side 1/2 (area 1/4), so Area(R) = 1 − 1/4 = 3/4. Hence c = 1/(3/4) = 4/3.

Thus, the birds will use the call in 5% of the cases where there is no predator nearby. In a given area, it is known that the probability that there is a predator near birds of this species is 5%.

explanation:
Let P = “predator nearby” and C = “call heard”. Given P(P)=0.05, P(C|P)=0.80, P(C|P^c)=0.05. By Bayes’ theorem with total probability:
P(C)=0.8·0.05+0.05·0.95=7/80. Hence
P(P|C)=[0.8·0.05]/[7/80]=(1/25)/(7/80)=(1/25)·(80/7)=16/35.

explanation_pitfalls: Ignoring the low base rate P(P)=0.05

explanation: Interarrival times are i.i.d. Exp(λ). By memorylessness, the residual (forward) waiting time seen at an arbitrary arrival time is also Exp(λ). Therefore, the expected waiting time is 1/λ.

Use memoryless property: residual waiting time has the same Exp(λ) law.

explanation: Let A={|Y−X|<1/2} and B={|Y+X|<1/2}. Use the orthogonal transform U=(Y−X)/√2, V=(Y+X)/√2. Since X,Y are iid N(0,1), U and V are independent N(0,1). Then A⇔|U|<a and B⇔|V|<a with a=1/(2√2)=√(1/8). Thus P(A)=P(B)=2Φ(a)−1 and, by independence, P(A∩B)=[2Φ(a)−1]^2. By inclusion–exclusion, P(A∪B)=2[2Φ(a)−1]−[2Φ(a)−1]^2=8Φ(a)−4Φ(a)^2−3 with a=√(1/8).
explanation_key_steps: Rewrite the shaded region as A={|Y−X|<1/2} and B={|Y+X|<1/2}.
Rotate/scale: U=(Y−X)/√2, V=(Y+X)/√2 ⇒ U,V iid N(0,1).
Apply inclusion–exclusion to get union probability.
explanation_formulae: U,V ~ iid N(0,1) via orthogonal transform
explanation_pitfalls: Using √(1/2) instead of √(1/8) when standardizing.
Forgetting to subtract the intersection of the two strips.
Assuming U and V are dependent; they are independent due to the orthogonal transform of iid normals.

explanation:
Use the law of total expectation. For Exponential(rate λ), mean = 1/λ.
- Y ~ Exponential(2) ⇒ E[Y] = 1/2.
- Given Y = y, X|Y=y ~ Exponential(1/y) ⇒ E[X|Y=y] = 1/(1/y) = y.
Thus, E[X] = E[E[X|Y]] = E[Y] = 1/2.

Apply law of total expectation: E[X] = E[Y]

Misreading Exponential(1/y) as mean 1/y instead of rate 1/y

english.context: Let X₁, …, X_(n) be independent Poisson-distributed random variables with parameter λ.
english.question: The conditional distribution of X₁ given X₁ + X₂ + ⋯ + X_(n) = m is

explanation:
Let S = X₁+⋯+Xₙ ~ Poisson(nλ). For k=0,…,m,
P(X₁=k | S=m) = P(X₁=k) P(S−X₁=m−k)/P(S=m)
= [e^{-λ} λ^k/k!][e^{-(n−1)λ}((n−1)λ)^{m−k}/(m−k)!] / [e^{-nλ} (nλ)^m/m!]
= C(m,k) (1/n)^k (1−1/n)^{m−k}.
Thus X₁ | S=m ~ Binomial(m, 1/n). (In general, conditional on the sum, the vector is multinomial with probabilities proportional to the λ’s.)
explanation_key_steps: Write conditional as joint over marginal using independence
Plug in Poisson pmfs for X₁, the sum of the rest, and S
Simplify to the binomial pmf with p = 1/n
explanation_pitfalls: Mistaking the conditional law for Poisson or geometric
Using p = 1/(1+λ) instead of p = 1/n

danish.context: Levetiden af en elektronisk komponent kan med god tilnærmelse beskrives ved en gamma (2, λ) fordelt stokastisk variabel. Komponenten har opnået alderen t > 0.
danish.question: Under de givne oplysninger, hvad er da sandsynligheden for, at komponenten fejler netop i intervallet [t, t + dt]. Svaret kan eventuelt angives approksimativt
options: $\frac{\lambda(1+\lambda t) e^{-\lambda t}}{1-(1+\lambda t) e^{-\lambda t}} \mathrm{~d} t$

english.context: The lifetime of an electronic component can be well approximated by a Gamma(2, λ)-distributed random variable. The component has reached age t > 0.
english.question: Given this information, what is the probability that the component fails exactly in the interval [t, t + dt]? The answer may be given approximately.
options: $\frac{\lambda(1+\lambda t) e^{-\lambda t}}{1-(1+\lambda t) e^{-\lambda t}} \mathrm{~d} t$

explanation: For T ~ Gamma(2, λ) with shape 2 and rate λ, the pdf is f(t) = λ^2 t e^{-λ t}. The (unconditional) small-interval probability that T falls in [t, t+dt] is approximately f(t) dt = λ^2 t e^{-λ t} dt, which matches option 1.
explanation_key_steps: Write the Gamma(2, λ) pdf: f(t)=λ^2 t e^{-λ t).
Use small-interval approximation: P(t ≤ T < t+dt) ≈ f(t) dt.
Match to the option: λ^2 t e^{-λ t} dt = λ(λ t)e^{-λ t} dt.
explanation_pitfalls: Confusing unconditional small-interval probability f(t)dt with the conditional (given survival to t) probability h(t)dt = [f(t)/S(t)]dt.
final_result_text: Approximately λ^2 t e^{-λ t} dt = λ(λ t)e^{-λ t} dt.

danish.context: Vi betragter de to stokastiske variable N og X, hvorom der gælder, P(N = n) = (1 - p)^(n - 1)p, n = 1, 2, 3, …, og, at den betingede fordeling af X givet N er en gamma (N, λ) fordeling.
danish.question: Den stokastiske variabel X har tætheden

english.context: We consider the two random variables N and X, for which it holds that P(N = n) = (1 - p)^(n - 1)p, n = 1, 2, 3, …, and that the conditional distribution of X given N is a gamma (N, λ) distribution.
english.question: The random variable X has density

explanation:
Let N~Geom(p) on {1,2,...} and X|N=n ~ Gamma(shape=n, rate=λ) with density f_{X|N=n}(x)=λ^n x^{n-1}e^{-λx}/(n-1)!, x>0. Then
f_X(x)=∑_{n=1}^∞ P(N=n)f_{X|N}(x|n)=∑_{n=1}^∞ p(1-p)^{n-1} [λ^n x^{n-1}e^{-λx}/(n-1)!]
= pλ e^{-λx} ∑_{n=1}^∞ [((1-p)λx)^{n-1}/(n-1)!] = pλ e^{-λx} e^{(1-p)λx} = pλ e^{-pλx}, x>0.
Hence X ~ Exp(rate = pλ).
explanation_key_steps: Use law of total probability: f_X(x)=∑ P(N=n) f_{X|N=n}(x).
Plug Gamma(n,λ) pdf and Geom(p) pmf on {1,2,...}.
Recognize the exponential series to sum the mixture.
Simplify to pλ e^{-pλx} for x>0.
explanation_pitfalls: Mixing up Gamma parameterization (rate vs scale).
Using a geometric starting at 0 instead of 1 changes powers.
Forgetting the support x>0.

danish.context: Idet X₁ og X₂ er uafhængige identisk fordelte stokastiske variable med fordelingsfunktion P(X_(i)≤x) = F(x), i = 1, 2, danner man parret X₍₁₎ = min_(i)X_(i), X₍₂₎ = max_(i)X_(i).
danish.question: Den simultane fordelingsfunktion F^(*)(x, y) = P(X₍₁₎≤x,X₍₂₎≤y) findes til

english.context: Given that X₁ and X₂ are independent identically distributed random variables with distribution function P(X_(i)≤x) = F(x), i = 1, 2, we form the pair X₍₁₎ = min_(i)X_(i), X₍₂₎ = max_(i)X_(i).
english.question: The joint distribution function F^(*)(x, y) = P(X₍₁₎≤x, X₍₂₎≤y) is given by

explanation:
Assume x ≤ y. Then {X_(1) ≤ x, X_(2) ≤ y} means both observations are ≤ y, but not both in (x, y]. By independence:
- P(both ≤ y) = F(y)^2.
- P(both in (x, y]) = [F(y) − F(x)]^2.
Hence F^*(x, y) = F(y)^2 − [F(y) − F(x)]^2 for x ≤ y. For x > y, X_(2) ≤ y implies X_(1) ≤ y ≤ x, so F^*(x, y) = F(y)^2. The selected option matches the x ≤ y case (the usual support x ≤ y).
explanation_key_steps: Express the event as within {both ≤ y} but excluding {both in (x, y]}.
Note the piecewise behavior: x ≤ y vs. x > y.
explanation_formulae: For x > y: F^*(x, y) = F(y)^2
explanation_pitfalls: Do not apply F(y)^2 − [F(y) − F(x)]^2 when x > y.
Independence is required to square probabilities.

danish.context: En speciel hjemmeside er meget belastet og kan kun vanskeligt hentes frem. Sandsynligheden for, at siden vises korrekt, er $\frac{1}{3}$ per gang uafhængigt af antallet af tidligere fejlslagne fors ⌀ g.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at siden vises korrekt første gang ved netop tredje forsøg, er

english.context: A particular website is heavily loaded and can only be retrieved with difficulty. The probability that the page is displayed correctly is $\frac{1}{3}$ each time, independent of the number of previous failed attempts.
english.question: The probability that the page is displayed correctly for the first time on exactly the third attempt is

explanation: Let success (correct display) have probability p = 1/3 independently each attempt. The time to first success X is geometric: P(X = k) = (1 − p)^{k−1} p. For k = 3: P(X = 3) = (2/3)^2 · (1/3) = 4/27.
explanation_key_steps: Model attempts as i.i.d. with success probability p = 1/3.
explanation_pitfalls: Do not compute (1/3)^3; that would be three successes, not first success on the third attempt.

danish.context: Parret ( X, Y ) af stokastiske variable, der er standard bivariat normalfordelt med korrelationskoefficient $\frac{3}{5}$, angiver et punkt i et sædvanligt to-dimensionalt koordinatsystem.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden P(|X| ≤ 1 ∣ Y = 1) findes til

english.context: The pair (X, Y) of random variables, which is standard bivariate normal with correlation coefficient \frac{3}{5}, represents a point in a usual two-dimensional coordinate system.
english.question: The probability P(|X| ≤ 1 | Y = 1) is

explanation: For a standard bivariate normal with correlation ρ, the conditional is X|Y=y ~ N(ρy, 1−ρ²). With ρ=3/5 and y=1, μ=3/5 and σ=4/5. Then P(|X|≤1|Y=1)=Φ((1−μ)/σ)−Φ((−1−μ)/σ)=Φ(1/2)−Φ(−2)=Φ(1/2)+Φ(2)−1.
explanation_key_steps: Compute μ=3/5 and σ=4/5 for y=1.
explanation_pitfalls: Using 1−ρ instead of 1−ρ² for the variance.
Sign mistakes when standardizing the lower bound.
Mixing up Φ (CDF) and φ (PDF).

danish.context: Parret ( X, Y ) af stokastiske variable er ligefordelt på området begrænset af koordinatsystemets akser og linien x + y = 1. Man definerer $Z=\frac{Y}{X}$.
danish.question: I værdimængden for Z findes tætheden f_(Z)(z) til

english.context: The pair (X, Y) of random variables is uniformly distributed over the region bounded by the coordinate axes and the line x + y = 1. Define $Z=\frac{Y}{X}$.
english.question: On the support of Z, the density f_(Z)(z) equals

knowledge_points: Uniform distribution on a triangular region
explanation: (X,Y) is uniform on T = {(x,y): x≥0, y≥0, x+y≤1}, so f_{X,Y}(x,y)=2 on T. Let Z=Y/X and use transformation (x,z) ↦ (x,y=zx). Jacobian |∂(x,y)/∂(x,z)| = x. For fixed z≥0, the constraint x+zx≤1 gives 0≤x≤1/(1+z). Thus f_{X,Z}(x,z)=2x on 0≤x≤1/(1+z). Integrate out x: f_Z(z)=∫_0^{1/(1+z)} 2x dx = 1/(1+z)^2, z≥0 (and 0 otherwise).
explanation_key_steps: Identify f_{X,Y}(x,y)=2 on x≥0, y≥0, x+y≤1
explanation_pitfalls: Including z<0 in the support (impossible since x,y≥0)
Forgetting the Jacobian factor x
Mishandling the upper limit x≤1/(1+z)

danish.question: Sandsynligheden P(X²<10) findes til

english.question: The probability P(X²<10) is found to be

explanation: We need the probability for the support values whose magnitudes are less than 10, i.e., x ∈ {−3, 0, 2, 4, 7}. Sum their PMF masses (or use the complement of {10, 12}). This gives 11/15.
explanation_key_steps: Optionally verify by complement: 1 − P(10) − P(12).
explanation_pitfalls: Accidentally including 10 or 12 in the sum.
Overlooking negative values that also satisfy the condition.

danish.context: Parret ( X, Y ) af stokastiske variable, der er standard bivariat normalfordelt med korrelationskoefficient $\frac{1}{2}$, angiver et punkt i et sædvanligt to-dimensionalt koordinatsystem.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at punktet ( X, Y ) ligger i første kvadrant mellem linierne $y=\frac{x}{2}$ og y = 2x, findes til

english.context: The pair ( X, Y ) of random variables, which is standard bivariate normally distributed with correlation coefficient $\frac{1}{2}$, represents a point in an ordinary two-dimensional coordinate system.
english.question: The probability that the point ( X, Y ) lies in the first quadrant between the lines $y=\frac{x}{2}$ and y = 2x is

explanation: Whiten the correlated normal so angles become uniform. Take U=X and V=(Y−ρX)/√(1−ρ²); then (U,V) are independent N(0,1). A ray y=kx maps to V/U=(k−ρ)/√(1−ρ²), so its angle is θ′=arctan((k−ρ)/√(1−ρ²)). For ρ=1/2 and k∈[1/2,2], we get θ′ from arctan(0) to arctan(√3)=π/3. With U>0 (first quadrant), probability is angular width over 2π: (π/3)/(2π)=1/6.
explanation_key_steps: Whiten: U=X, V=(Y−ρX)/√(1−ρ²) ⇒ (U,V) ~ i.i.d. N(0,1), angle uniform.
Plug ρ=1/2, k∈[1/2,2] ⇒ V/U ∈ [0,√3] ⇒ angular width π/3.
explanation_pitfalls: Angle is not uniform in (X,Y); whiten first to use angular uniformity, and enforce X>0 → U>0.

danish.context: For nyligt har man anslået, at der gennemsnitligt er 4 planeter per 1000 kubiklysår i mælkevejen indenfor den såkaldte "goldilock" afstand fra deres stjerne, hvor vand kan forekomme i flydende form. Det antages approksimativt, at tætheden af planeter er homogen gennem hele mælkevejen.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at der vil være mindst en planet med mulighed for vand i flydende tilstand, i en terning med sidelængden 8 lysår i mælkevejen, findes til

english.context: Recently it has been estimated that on average there are 4 planets per 1000 cubic light-years in the Milky Way within the so-called 'Goldilocks' distance from their star, where water can exist in liquid form. It is approximately assumed that the density of planets is homogeneous throughout the entire Milky Way.
english.question: The probability that there will be at least one planet where water can be in liquid form, in a cube with side length 8 light-years in the Milky Way, is

explanation: Model the count of Goldilocks-zone planets in a fixed volume by a Poisson process with mean λ = (density)×(volume). For this 8-ly-side cube, λ ≈ 1, so the probability of at least one is P(N ≥ 1) = 1 − e^{−λ} ≈ 1 − e^{−1} ≈ 0.632.
explanation_key_steps: Model counts with a Poisson(λ) for a homogeneous spatial density.
Compute the mean λ for the cube (≈ 1).
Use the complement rule: P(N ≥ 1) = 1 − e^{−λ}.
explanation_pitfalls: Not using the complement 1 − P(N=0) for “at least one”.
Confusing the mean count λ with the probability directly.

danish.context: Tre personer ankommer tilfældigt til et advokatkontor i løbet af en time.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at den anden person, der ankommer, ankommer efter
options: 0 minutter og inden 40 minutter, findes til

english.context: Three people arrive randomly at a law office over the course of one hour.
english.question: The probability that the second person to arrive arrives after

explanation:
Let arrival times be i.i.d. Uniform(0,60). Scale to X_i = T_i/60 ~ Uniform(0,1). The second order statistic X_(2) for n=3 has Beta(2,2) distribution with pdf f(x)=6x(1−x) and CDF F(x)=∫_0^x 6t(1−t)dt = 3x^2−2x^3.
We want P(20 < T_(2) < 40) = P(1/3 < X_(2) < 2/3) = F(2/3)−F(1/3).
Compute: F(2/3)=3(4/9)−2(8/27)=20/27 and F(1/3)=3(1/9)−2(1/27)=7/27.
Thus P = 20/27 − 7/27 = 13/27.
explanation_key_steps: Model arrivals as i.i.d. Uniform(0,60) and rescale to [0,1].
Use that X_(2) for n=3 is Beta(2,2) with CDF F(x)=3x^2−2x^3.
Evaluate F at 2/3 and 1/3 and subtract to get the probability.
explanation_pitfalls: Forgetting to rescale minutes to the unit interval.
Using wrong Beta parameters for the 2nd order statistic.
Including endpoints; they have probability zero so do not affect the result.

english.question: One finds P(E(Y | X) ≥ 1) to be
options: The question does not make sense

explanation: Given Y|X=x ~ Bin(x, 1/2), we have E(Y|X=x)=x/2, so E(Y|X)≥1 ⇔ X≥2. For a Poisson(λ), P(X≥2)=1−[P(X=0)+P(X=1)]=1−e^{-λ}(1+λ), which matches 1−2/e among the options.
explanation_pitfalls: Do not confuse E(Y|X) (a function of X) with E(Y).

danish.question: Tætheden for førstekoordinaten X findes til

english.context: A point is chosen at random in the region shown in the figure below. [image]
english.question: The density of the first coordinate X is found to be

explanation: Because the point is uniform on the region, the marginal density f_X(x) equals the vertical cross-sectional length w(x) divided by the total area A. From the figure, the vertical boundaries at abscissa x are y_upper = (1/2)x^2 and y_lower = x, so w(x) = (1/2)x^2 − x on the x-support (and 0 otherwise). The total area (from the figure) is A = ∫ w(x) dx = 12. Hence f_X(x) = w(x)/A = (1/12)((1/2)x^2 − x) on its support (0 otherwise).
explanation_key_steps: Uniform on region ⇒ f_X(x) = cross-sectional width w(x) / total area A.
Read off boundaries: y_upper = (1/2)x^2, y_lower = x ⇒ w(x) = (1/2)x^2 − x (on support).
Normalize by total area A = ∫ w(x) dx = 12.
State f_X(x) on its x-support, 0 otherwise.
explanation_pitfalls: Using the wrong order of upper-minus-lower curve when forming w(x).
Forgetting to restrict to the x-support or to normalize by the total area.

danish.context: Om hændelserne A og B oplyses, at sandsynligheden for, at hændelse A indtræffer, er $\frac{2}{7}$, mens sandsynligheden for, at B også indtræffer, når det vides, at A indtræffer, er $\frac{14}{23}$.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at både A og B indtræffer, er

english.context: Regarding events A and B, it is given that the probability that event A occurs is $\frac{2}{7}$, while the probability that B also occurs given that A occurs is $\frac{14}{23}$.
english.question: The probability that both A and B occur is

explanation: Use the multiplication rule for conditional probability: P(A ∩ B) = P(A)·P(B|A). Substitute P(A)=2/7 and P(B|A)=14/23 to get (2/7)(14/23) = 28/161 = 4/23.
explanation_pitfalls: Confusing P(B|A) with P(A|B).
Adding instead of multiplying for joint probability.

danish.context: Man betragter en stokastisk variabel X, der følger en gamma (2, λ)-fordeling, og danner en ny variabel $Y=\frac{1}{X}$.

english.context: Consider a random variable X that follows a gamma (2, λ) distribution, and form a new variable $Y=\frac{1}{X}$.

explanation: Let X ~ Gamma(α=2, rate λ), so f_X(x)=λ^2 x e^{-λx}, x>0. With Y=1/X, we have x=1/y (y>0) and |dx/dy|=1/y^2. Hence f_Y(y)=f_X(1/y)|dx/dy|=λ^2(1/y)e^{-λ/y}(1/y^2)=(λ^2/y^3)e^{-λ/y}, y>0.
explanation_key_steps: Use Gamma(2, rate λ): f_X(x)=λ^2 x e^{-λx}
Apply change of variables and simplify to y^{-3} factor
explanation_pitfalls: Mixing rate λ with scale 1/λ
Forgetting the Jacobian factor 1/y^2
Not restricting to y>0

Placeringen af planterne i anden generation kan i et passende normeret koordinatsystem, hvor den oprindelige plante er placeret i koordinatsystemets nulpunkt, beskrives ved uafhængige standardiserede normalfordelte variable.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at en tilfældig valgt plante i anden generation er lokaliseret i en afstand mellem $\frac{1}{2}$ og 1 længdeenhed fra den oprindelige plante, er

english.context: A giant hogweed (plant) was at some point introduced to an area. The locations of the plants in the second generation can, in a suitably normalized coordinate system where the original plant is placed at the origin, be described by independent standard normally distributed variables.
english.question: The probability that a randomly selected plant in the second generation is located at a distance between $\frac{1}{2}$ and 1 unit of length from the original plant is

explanation: With X,Y ~ iid N(0,1), the radius R = sqrt(X^2+Y^2) is Rayleigh: f_R(r)=r e^{-r^2/2}, r≥0. Thus P(a≤R≤b)=∫_a^b r e^{-r^2/2} dr = e^{-a^2/2}−e^{-b^2/2}. Plugging a=1/2, b=1 gives e^{-1/8}−e^{-1/2}.
explanation_key_steps: Use R = sqrt(X^2+Y^2) ~ Rayleigh with pdf r e^{-r^2/2}.
Integrate from 1/2 to 1 to obtain e^{-1/8} − e^{-1/2}.
explanation_pitfalls: Using the 1D normal CDF Φ for the radial distance.
Confusing R with R^2 (which is χ²₂/exponential).

danish.context: Lad X₁, X₂, … være uafhængige eksponential ( λ ) fordelte variable og lad N være geometrisk ( p ) fordelt, i.e. P(N = n) = (1 - p)^(n - 1)p, n = 1, 2, ….
danish.question: Middelværdien E(X₁+X₂⋯+X_(N)) af $\sum_{i=1}^{N} X_{i}$ findes til

english.context: Let X₁, X₂, … be independent exponential (λ) distributed variables and let N be geometric (p) distributed, i.e., P(N = n) = (1 - p)^(n - 1)p, n = 1, 2, ….
english.question: The mean E(X₁+X₂⋯+X_(N)) of $\sum_{i=1}^{N} X_{i}$ is found to be

explanation:
- For Xi ~ Exp(λ), E[X1] = 1/λ.
- By conditioning on N (independent of {Xi}): E[∑_{i=1}^N X_i | N] = N · (1/λ) ⇒ E[∑_{i=1}^N X_i] = E[N]/λ.
- With the geometric on {1,2,...} parameterized so that P(N=n)=p^{n-1}(1-p), we have E[N] = 1/(1-p).
- Hence E[∑_{i=1}^N X_i] = 1/(λ(1-p)).
explanation_key_steps: Apply law of total expectation/Wald: E[sum]=E[N]·E[X1]
explanation_pitfalls: Geometric mean depends on parameterization; if instead E[N]=1/p (when P(N=n)=(1-p)^{n-1}p), the result would be 1/(λp). Independence of N and {Xi} is required.

danish.context: I en kasse med 50 nyhøstede æbler er der talt 5 rådne æbler. Man antager, at denne kasse er repræsentativ for æbleplantagen, den kommer fra.

options: 00 rådne æbler i en høst på 3600 æbler

english.context: In a box with 50 newly harvested apples, 5 rotten apples have been counted. It is assumed that this box is representative of the apple orchard it comes from.
english.question: State, possibly approximately, the probability that there are more than
options: 00 rotten apples in a harvest of 3600 apples

explanation: From 5/50 we estimate p ≈ 0.1. For a harvest of n = 3600, X ~ Bin(3600, 0.1). We want P(X > 300) = 1 − P(X ≤ 300). The exact cumulative probability P(X ≤ 300) is ∑_{i=0}^{300} C(3600,i)(0.1)^i(0.9)^{3600−i}, which matches option 1; the desired probability is its complement.
explanation_key_steps: Model rotten count as X ~ Bin(3600, 0.1).
Recognize P(X ≤ 300) as the binomial CDF sum (option 1).

Using the wrong n in the binomial coefficient (it is 3600).
Mixing decimal comma and point; p = 0.1 = 0,1.

english.context: A man rolls a fair die until he gets the same number of pips twice in a row. Let X denote the total number of rolls he uses.
english.question: The probabilities P(X = k) for k ∈ N are given by

explanation: Consider the transitions between consecutive rolls. Starting from roll 2, each transition matches the previous roll with probability 1/6 and does not match with probability 5/6, independently of earlier outcomes. X=k means the first k−2 transitions are non-matches and the (k−1)→k transition is a match, so P(X=k)=(5/6)^{k−2}(1/6) for k≥2; P(X=1)=0.
explanation_key_steps: Model consecutive-equality events from i=2 onward.
Use P(match)=1/6 and independence across transitions.
Require k−2 non-matches followed by 1 match.
explanation_pitfalls: X cannot be 1; at least two rolls are needed.
The first roll only sets the reference; it does not affect the probabilities beyond that.

english.context: The expected number of people infected with Covid-19 during a week in a given municipality is 50. The variability is described by a standard deviation that is likewise 50.
english.question: The best upper bound for the probability that there are more than 500 infected in the municipality in a particular week is found to be

explanation: Model the weekly count as Poisson with mean λ=50. Then the probability of more than 500 infections is the Poisson upper tail, which gives the exact value and thus the tightest possible upper bound among the options: a tail sum of the PMF from 500 to ∞. Normal-tail options are unjustified; Chebyshev/Markov bounds (1/81, 1/10) are far looser.
explanation_key_steps: Express P(X ≥ 500) as the Poisson PMF tail sum
Select the exact tail expression as the tightest upper bound among choices
explanation_pitfalls: Using Chebyshev or Markov yields very loose bounds
Applying normal tails without justification

danish.context: Man har udviklet en sandsynlighedsmodel til beskrivelse af bestanden af to kænguruarter. Der er tilstrækkeligt mange individer til, at en bivariat normalfordeling kan bruges som model. Det forventede antal af dyr af hver af de to arter er 800, variansen for antallet af dyr er for begge arter 25600 , mens korrelationskoefficienten er ρ.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at det totale antal dyr ikke er større end 1400, findes til

english.context: A probabilistic model has been developed to describe the population of two kangaroo species. There are sufficiently many individuals that a bivariate normal distribution can be used as a model. The expected number of animals of each of the two species is 800, the variance of the number of animals is 25600 for both species, while the correlation coefficient is ρ.
english.question: The probability that the total number of animals is not greater than 1400 is given by

explanation:
Let X,Y be the counts with E[X]=E[Y]=800, Var(X)=Var(Y)=25600, Corr(X,Y)=ρ. Then S=X+Y is normal with mean μ_S=1600 and variance Var(S)=Var(X)+Var(Y)+2Cov(X,Y)=25600+25600+2·ρ·160·160=51200(1+ρ). Thus σ_S=160√2√(1+ρ). Therefore
P(S≤1400)=Φ((1400−1600)/σ_S)=Φ(−200/(160√2√(1+ρ)))=Φ(−5√2/(8√(1+ρ)))=Φ(−5√2√(1+ρ)/(8(1+ρ))). This matches option 2.
explanation_key_steps: Compute S=X+Y: μ_S=1600 by linearity of expectation.
Use Var(S)=Var(X)+Var(Y)+2Cov(X,Y) with Cov=ρσ_Xσ_Y and σ_X=σ_Y=160.
Standardize S to Z and express the probability via Φ.
explanation_pitfalls: Forgetting the 2·Cov(X,Y) term in Var(X+Y).
Arithmetic slip turning 8 into 16 in the denominator.
Dropping the dependence on ρ when standardizing.

danish.context: Fabriksfremstillede teboller har en vis variation i størrelsen. Afvigelsen kan på en passende normeret skala beskrives ved tæthedsfunktionen $f(x)=6\left(\frac{1}{2}+x\right)\left(\frac{1}{2}-x\right)$ for $-\frac{1}{2}<x<\frac{1}{2}$.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at den numeriske afvigelse højest er $\frac{1}{4}$ på den normerede skala, findes til

english.context: Factory-produced tea buns have some variation in size. The deviation can, on a suitably normalized scale, be described by the density function f(x)=6\left(\frac{1}{2}+x\right)\left(\frac{1}{2}-x\right) for -\frac{1}{2}<x<\frac{1}{2}.
english.question: The probability that the numerical deviation is at most \frac{1}{4} on the normalized scale is found to be

explanation_key_steps: Integrate over [−1/4,1/4] using symmetry and evaluate.
explanation_pitfalls: Forgetting absolute value (|x|).
Missing the symmetry factor 2.
Arithmetic slips in evaluating the integral.

danish.context: For at estimere vildtpopulationen i et reservat skydes 25 bjørne med bedøvende pile og mærkes. På et senere tidspunkt skydes 5 bjørne, hvoraf de 2 var mærkede.
danish.question: Under antagelse af, at den samlede population er 75 , hvad er da sandsynligheden for at få netop 2 mærkede blandt de 5 skudte.

english.context: To estimate the wildlife population in a reserve, 25 bears are shot with tranquilizer darts and tagged. At a later time, 5 bears are shot, of which 2 were tagged.
english.question: Assuming that the total population is 75, what is the probability of getting exactly 2 marked among the 5 shot?

explanation: Sampling is without replacement from a finite population, so the count of tagged bears follows a hypergeometric distribution with N=75, K=25 tagged, and n=5 draws. The probability of exactly k=2 tagged is choose 2 from 25 and 3 from 50, divided by choose 5 from 75.
explanation_pitfalls: Using a binomial or Poisson model instead of hypergeometric.
Choosing k=3 instead of k=2.

danish.context: Hos en fabrikant af spil undersøger man, om almindelige sekssidede terninger er korrekt afbalancerede ved at undersøge antallet af enkeltkast, der giver et lige antal øjne.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for højst 2 gange at få et lige antal øjne ved 6 kast med en afbalanceret terning er

english.context: At a game manufacturer, they investigate whether ordinary six-sided dice are properly balanced by examining the number of individual throws that yield an even number of pips.
english.question: The probability of getting an even number of pips at most 2 times in 6 throws with a balanced die is

explanation: Let X be the number of even outcomes in 6 throws. For a fair die, P(even)=3/6=1/2, so X~Bin(6,1/2). We want P(X≤2): P(X≤2)=∑_{i=0}^2 C(6,i)(1/2)^i(1/2)^{6−i}=(1/2)^6∑_{i=0}^2 C(6,i)=(1/64)∑_{i=0}^2 C(6,i)=11/32.
explanation_key_steps: Model number of evens as X~Bin(6,1/2)
Sum the binomial PMF for i=0,1,2
Factor out (1/2)^6 to match the option
explanation_pitfalls: Using p=1/3 instead of 1/2 for an even outcome
Taking the complement (X≥3) instead of at most 2

danish.context: Et punkt i området afgrænset af linierne y = x, y = x + 2, y = 6 og x = 0 vælges tilfældigt.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at x-koordinaten er større end 4, findes til

english.context: A point in the region bounded by the lines y = x, y = x + 2, y = 6, and x = 0 is chosen at random.
english.question: The probability that the x-coordinate is greater than 4 is

explanation:
The region is the quadrilateral with vertices (0,0), (0,2), (4,6), (6,6). Using vertical slices:
- For 0 ≤ x ≤ 4: height = (x+2) − x = 2.
- For 4 ≤ x ≤ 6: height = 6 − x.
Total area A = ∫_0^4 2 dx + ∫_4^6 (6−x) dx = 8 + 2 = 10.
For x > 4, the area is A_{x>4} = ∫_4^6 (6−x) dx = 2.
Probability = A_{x>4}/A = 2/10 = 1/5.
explanation_key_steps: Identify the polygon and its x-intervals for vertical slicing
explanation_pitfalls: Using a uniform density 1/12 instead of 1/Area = 1/10
Assuming the band has constant height 2 for all 0 ≤ x ≤ 6 (ignoring the y=6 cap)

danish.context: Det oplyses, at tætheden for den stokastiske variabel Y er gamma (4, 1), mens tætheden for den stokastiske variabel X for givet Y er $f_{X \mid Y=y}(x)=6 \frac{x}{y^{2}}\left(1-\frac{x}{y}\right)$, hvor 0 ≤ x ≤ y.
danish.question: Tætheden f_(X)(x) for X findes til

english.context: It is stated that the density of the random variable Y is gamma (4, 1), while the density of the random variable X given Y is $f_{X \mid Y=y}(x)=6 \frac{x}{y^{2}}\left(1-\frac{x}{y}\right)$, where 0  x  y.
english.question: The density f_(X)(x) for X is found to be

explanation: Use the law of total probability: f_X(x)=∫_{x}^{∞} f_{X|Y}(x|y) f_Y(y) dy, since 0≤x≤y. With Y~Gamma(4,1), f_Y(y)=y^3 e^{-y}/6. Multiply and simplify: 6·(x/y^2)(1−x/y)·(y^3 e^{-y}/6)=x(y−x)e^{-y}. Thus f_X(x)=∫_{x}^{∞} x(y−x)e^{-y} dy = x e^{-x}, x>0. This matches the integral form in option 5.
explanation_key_steps: Set up f_X(x)=∫_{y=x}^{∞} f_{X|Y}(x|y) f_Y(y) dy
Evaluate ∫_{x}^{∞}(y−x)e^{-y} dy = e^{-x} to get f_X(x)=x e^{-x}
explanation_pitfalls: Forgetting the integration lower limit is y=x (support 0≤x≤y)
Dropping the factor x, incorrectly choosing e^{-x} (option 2)
Using an incorrect Gamma(4,1) density
final_result_text: f_X(x)=x e^{-x}, for x>0 (equivalently, ∫_{x}^{∞} x(y−x)e^{-y} dy).

danish.context: Et almindeligt spil kort har 52 kort, hvoraf 4 er esser og 13 er spar. Ud af et sådant spil trækkes en hånd bestående af 4 kort uden tilbagelægning. Der gives nu point, således at hvert es tæller 10 points, og hver spar tæller 1 point. (Spar es tæller således både som es og som spar).
danish.question: Det forventede samlede antal points på en hånd er

english.context: A standard deck of cards has 52 cards, of which 4 are aces and 13 are spades. From such a deck, a hand consisting of 4 cards is drawn without replacement. Points are awarded so that each ace counts as 10 points, and each spade counts as 1 point. (The ace of spades therefore counts both as an ace and as a spade).
english.question: The expected total number of points in a hand is

explanation: Let A be the number of aces and S the number of spades in 4 cards. Points T = 10A + S (ace of spades counts in both). By linearity of expectation and the hypergeometric mean E[#successes]=n(K/N): E[A]=4*(4/52)=4/13 and E[S]=4*(13/52)=1. Hence E[T]=10*(4/13)+1=53/13.
explanation_key_steps: Apply hypergeometric mean E[#]=n(K/N) for aces and spades
Compute E[A]=4/13 and E[S]=1, sum to get 53/13
explanation_pitfalls: Double-count concern for ace of spades is handled automatically by linearity
Independence of draws is not required for expectation

danish.context: De stokastiske variable X og Y er to uafhængige binomial $\left(2, \frac{1}{2}\right)$ fordelte stokastiske variable.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden P(X - Y = 0) findes til

english.context: The random variables X and Y are two independent Binomial(2, 1/2)-distributed random variables.
english.question: The probability P(X - Y = 0) equals

explanation_key_steps: Use independence: sum of products P(X=k)P(Y=k)
Compute Bin(2,1/2) pmf values and sum squares
explanation_pitfalls: Confusing X−Y=0 with X=0
Forgetting independence when multiplying probabilities

danish.context: På en sømfabrik er der 3 maskiner A , B og C , der producerer søm. Deres produktion udgør henholdsvis $\frac{1}{4}, \frac{7}{20}$ og $\frac{2}{5}$ af hele produktionen. Deres fejlproduktionsrater er henholdsvis $\frac{1}{20}, \frac{1}{25}$ og $\frac{1}{50}$. Der udtages nu et tilfældigt søm fra produktionen og dette findes til at være defekt.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at det udtagne søm stammer fra maskine A, findes til

english.context: At a nail factory there are 3 machines A, B, and C that produce nails. Their production amounts to $\frac{1}{4}, \frac{7}{20}$ and $\frac{2}{5}$ of the total production, respectively. Their defect rates are $\frac{1}{20}, \frac{1}{25}$ and $\frac{1}{50}$, respectively. A nail is now randomly selected from the production and is found to be defective.
english.question: The probability that the selected nail came from machine A is

explanation_key_steps: Identify priors P(A), P(B), P(C) and defect rates P(D|A), P(D|B), P(D|C).
explanation_pitfalls: Using only P(D|A)P(A) without normalizing by total defect probability.
Arithmetic slips when converting to a common denominator.
Mixing up prior production shares with defect rates.

danish.context: Man betragter parret ( X, Y ) af stokastiske variable, der følger en ligefordeling over området 0 < x < y < 1. Man danner Z = X + Y.
danish.question: Tætheden f_(Z)(z) findes til

english.context: Consider the pair (X, Y) of random variables that follow a uniform distribution over the region 0 < x < y < 1. Define Z = X + Y.
english.question: The density f_(Z)(z) is

knowledge_points: Uniform distribution on a triangular region
explanation: The triangle 0<x<y<1 has area 1/2, so f_{X,Y}(x,y)=2 on it. For Z=X+Y, f_Z(z)=∫ 2·1_{0<x<z−x<1}·1_{x<z/2} dx, giving x∈(max(0,z−1), min(1,z/2)). Thus: for 0<z≤1, length=z/2 ⇒ f_Z(z)=z; for 1<z<2, length=1−z/2 ⇒ f_Z(z)=2−z (0 otherwise).
explanation_key_steps: Set f_Z(z)=∫ f_{X,Y}(x,z−x) dx with constraints
explanation_pitfalls: Forgetting x<y ⇒ x<z/2, altering limits
Assuming X and Y are independent (they are not)
final_result_text: f_Z(z)=z for 0<z≤1 and f_Z(z)=2−z for 1<z<2 (0 otherwise).

danish.context: Man har givet X og Y som to uafhængige Poisson(2) variable.
danish.question: Man finder den betingede fordeling P(X = x ∣ X + Y = 2) til

english.context: We are given X and Y as two independent Poisson(2) variables.
english.question: One finds the conditional distribution P(X = x ∣ X + Y = 2) to be

explanation: For independent Poisson(λ1) and Poisson(λ2), conditioning on the sum S=n yields X | (S=n) ~ Binomial(n, p) with p = λ1/(λ1+λ2). Here λ1=λ2=2, so p=1/2 and n=2, giving P(X=x | X+Y=2) = C(2,x)(1/2)^x(1/2)^{2−x} = C(2,x)/4 for x=0,1,2.
explanation_key_steps: Apply the known result: X | (X+Y=n) ~ Bin(n, λ1/(λ1+λ2)).
explanation_pitfalls: Treating the conditional distribution as Poisson instead of Binomial.
Forgetting the support is only x=0,1,2 when conditioning on X+Y=2.

danish.context: Man har givet den binomial $\left(10, \frac{1}{4}\right)$ fordelte stokastiske variabel X.
danish.question: Middelværdien E(X) er

english.context: We are given the binomially distributed random variable X with parameters $(10, \frac{1}{4})$.
english.question: The mean E(X) is

explanation: For X ~ Binomial(10, 1/4), the mean is E[X] = n·p = 10·(1/4) = 2.5. The expectation is a constant (a real number), not a random variable/event/function.
explanation_key_steps: Use binomial mean formula E[X] = n·p.
explanation_pitfalls: Confusing E[X] with the random variable X.
Mixing up the expectation operator with its numeric value.

danish.context: En ikke negativ kontinuert stokastisk variabel X har hazard rate h(x) = (x - 1)².
danish.question: Man finder P(X > 1) til
options: Spørgsmålet kan ikke besvares, funktionen h(x) kan ikke være en hazard  rate.

english.context: A nonnegative continuous random variable X has hazard rate h(x) = (x - 1)^2.
english.question: We find P(X > 1) to be
options: The question cannot be answered; the function h(x) cannot be a hazard rate.

explanation:
For a nonnegative continuous X with hazard h(x), the survival is S(x)=P(X>x)=exp(-∫_0^x h(t)dt). With h(t)=(t−1)^2,
H(1)=∫_0^1 (t−1)^2 dt = [t^3/3 − t^2 + t]_0^1 = 1/4, so P(X>1)=S(1)=e^{-1/4}.
explanation_key_steps: Use S(x)=exp(-∫_0^x h(t)dt) for hazard h.
explanation_pitfalls: Integrate the hazard from 0 to x (since X is nonnegative).
Confirm h(x)≥0 so it is a valid hazard.

danish.context: Betragt to uafhængige Poisson-fordelte variable X og Y med middelværdi μ_(x) og μ_(y).
danish.question: P(Y > X) bestemmes til

english.context: Consider two independent Poisson-distributed variables X and Y with means μ_(x) and μ_(y).
english.question: P(Y > X) is given by

explanation:
Since X and Y are independent Poisson, write the event as a double sum over disjoint outcomes:
P(Y > X) = Σ_{i=0}^∞ Σ_{j=i+1}^∞ P(X=i)P(Y=j).
Using Poisson PMFs and rearranging the sums yields
P(Y > X) = e^{-(μ_x+μ_y)} Σ_{j=1}^∞ (μ_y^j/j!) Σ_{i=0}^{j-1} (μ_x^i/i!).
This matches option 5; other options are approximations or for different models.
explanation_key_steps: Express P(Y > X) as Σ_i Σ_{j=i+1} P(X=i)P(Y=j).
Substitute Poisson PMFs and factor e^{-(μ_x+μ_y)}.
Swap order of summation to obtain the stated double series.
explanation_pitfalls: Confusing with exponential race result μ_y/(μ_x+μ_y).
Using normal approximation Φ((μ_y−μ_x)/√(μ_x+μ_y)) as exact.
Mixing > and ≥ in the inner sum limits.

danish.context: En aktieportefølje indeholder aktier fra to selskaber indenfor byggesektoren. Gevinsten på de to aktier kan beskrives ved en bivariat normalfordeling, hvor middelværdien på hver af aktierne er 100 , mens variansen for hver af dem er 20² = 400. Korrelationskoefficienten er $\rho=\frac{2}{3}$.
danish.question: Hvis den ene aktie har en værdi på 130 , hvad er da den forventede værdi af den anden aktie?

english.context: A stock portfolio contains shares from two companies in the construction sector. The returns on the two stocks can be described by a bivariate normal distribution, where the mean of each of the stocks is 100, while the variance for each of them is 20² = 400. The correlation coefficient is $\rho=\frac{2}{3}$.
english.question: If one stock has a value of 130, what is the expected value of the other stock?

explanation: For a bivariate normal with μX=μY=100, σX=σY=20, and ρ=2/3, the conditional mean is E[Y|X=x] = μY + ρ(σY/σX)(x−μX). With σY/σX=1 and x=130: 100 + (2/3)(30) = 120.
explanation_key_steps: Use the conditional expectation formula for bivariate normal.
explanation_pitfalls: Do not assume independence (ρ≠0).
Include the σY/σX factor (here it equals 1).

danish.context: Det antages, at skytters færdighed beskrives ved et (reelt) tal på en skala. Færdigheden på denne skala af en tilfældig skytte kan beskrives som en standard normalfordelt stokastisk variabel. Det oplyses yderligere, at sandsynligheden for, at en skytte med færdighed k på skalaen opnår mindst 200 point ved en skydekonkurrence, er $\frac{1}{2+k^{2}}$.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at en tilfældig valgt skytte opnår mindst 200 ved en skydekonkurrence, findes til

english.context: It is assumed that shooters' skill is described by a (real) number on a scale. The skill on this scale of a random shooter can be described as a standard normally distributed random variable. It is further given that the probability that a shooter with skill k on the scale achieves at least 200 points in a shooting competition is $\frac{1}{2+k^{2}}$.
english.question: The probability that a randomly chosen shooter achieves at least 200 points in a shooting competition is found to be

explanation:
Let K ~ N(0,1) be the skill. Given K=k, P(score ≥ 200 | K=k) = 1/(2+k^2). By the law of total probability (tower property),

P(score ≥ 200) = E[1/(2+K^2)] = ∫_{-∞}^{∞} (1/(2+x^2)) φ(x) dx, where φ is the standard normal pdf. This matches option 3. (It evaluates to (√π/2) e·erfc(1) ≈ 0.379.)
explanation_key_steps: Model skill K as standard normal
Write as the normal-weighted integral over ℝ
explanation_pitfalls: Do not plug in a fixed k; average over K via expectation
Do not use finite, k-dependent integration bounds; integrate over all x ∈ ℝ with normal weight

danish.context: Vi betragter området A afgrænset af linierne y = 2x - 1, y = 2x - 7, y = 3 og y = 1. Man vælger tilfældigt et punkt P i A og betegner det koordinat med parret af stokastiske variable (X, Y).
danish.question: Sandsynligheden P(Y < 5 - X) findes til

english.context: We consider the region A bounded by the lines y = 2x - 1, y = 2x - 7, y = 3 and y = 1. A point P in A is chosen at random and its coordinates are denoted by the pair of random variables (X, Y).
english.question: The probability P(Y < 5 - X) is

explanation: A is the parallelogram with vertices (1,1), (4,1), (5,3), (2,3). The line y = 5 − x passes through (4,1) and (2,3), i.e., it is a diagonal. A diagonal bisects the area of a parallelogram, so the portion with y < 5 − x occupies exactly half the area of A.
explanation_key_steps: Compute the vertices from intersections of the given lines.
Observe that y = 5 − x passes through opposite vertices (4,1) and (2,3), hence is a diagonal.
A diagonal divides a parallelogram into two equal-area regions; y < 5 − x selects one of them.
explanation_formulae: P = area({(x,y) ∈ A : y < 5 − x}) / area(A) = 1/2
explanation_pitfalls: Overcomplicating with integration instead of using the diagonal area-bisection property.

danish.context: Når en bil kommer til service, er der en sandsynlighed på 0,5 for, at bremseklodserne skal udskiftes. Givet, at bremseklodserne skal udskiftes, er der en sandsynlighed på 0,4 for, at bremseskiverne også skal udskiftes.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at både bremseklodser og bremseskiver skal udskiftes, når en bil kommer til service, findes til

english.context: When a car comes in for service, there is a probability of 0,5 that the brake pads need to be replaced. Given that the brake pads need to be replaced, there is a probability of 0,4 that the brake discs also need to be replaced.
english.question: The probability that both the brake pads and the brake discs need to be replaced when a car comes in for service is

explanation: Use the multiplication rule for conditional probability: if A = “pads need replacement” and B = “discs need replacement,” then P(A ∩ B) = P(A)·P(B | A). Given P(A) = 0,5 and P(B | A) = 0,4, we have 0,5 × 0,4 = 0,2.
explanation_key_steps: Define events: A = pads replaced, B = discs replaced.
Apply multiplication rule: P(A ∩ B) = P(A)·P(B | A).
explanation_pitfalls: No need to assume independence; use the given conditional probability.
Do not add probabilities.

danish.context: En positiv kontinuert stokastisk variabel T er kendetegnet ved $\lambda(t)=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{\mathrm{P}(T \in(t, t+h) \mid T>t)}{h}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{t}}$.
danish.question: Man finder $\mathrm{P}\left(T \leq \frac{1}{4}\right)$ til

english.context: A positive continuous random variable T is characterized by $\lambda(t)=\lim_{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{\mathrm{P}(T \in(t, t+h) \mid T>t)}{h}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{t}}$.
english.question: One finds $\mathrm{P}\left(T \leq \frac{1}{4}\right)$ to be

explanation: Hazard λ(t)=f(t)/S(t) implies S′(t)=−λ(t)S(t), S(0)=1, so S(t)=exp(−∫₀^t λ(u)du). With λ(u)=u^{-1/2}, ∫₀^t u^{-1/2}du=2√t, hence S(t)=e^{-2√t} and F(t)=1−e^{-2√t}. Evaluate at t=1/4: F(1/4)=1−e^{-1}.
explanation_pitfalls: Confusing hazard with density.
Forgetting S(0)=1 when solving for S(t).

danish.context: I et TV program med konkurrencer er der ved hver forestilling en sandsynlighed på præcis 10% for, at hovedprisen vindes.
danish.question: Sandsynligheden for, at prisen vindes første gang netop ved femte forestilling, er

english.context: In a TV game show, at each show there is a probability of exactly 10% that the grand prize is won.
english.question: The probability that the prize is won for the first time exactly at the fifth show is

explanation: Each show is an independent Bernoulli trial with success probability p=0.1. The time of the first success X is geometric: P(X=k)=(1−p)^{k−1}p. For k=5: P(X=5)=(0.9)^4·0.1.
explanation_key_steps: Model shows as independent Bernoulli trials with p=0.1.
explanation_pitfalls: Using Poisson or binomial instead of geometric for “first” success.
Multiplying by 4 or 5, which counts placements of success rather than first success only.

danish.context: En fabrik i Kina fremstiller legetøj til brug i forbindelse med salg af måltider på en fast food restaurant. Til en serie af legetøj benyttes en speciel plastikdel, der fremstilles meget billigt, men som også har en stor sandsynlighed for at være defekt, idet denne sandsynlighed er 30%. Man ønsker at beregne sandsynligheden for, at der i en produktion på 1000 styk fås netop mellem 675 og 725 (begge tal inklusive) fungerende enheder.
danish.question: Den ønskede sandsynlighed bestemmes eller tilnærmes bedst ved

english.context: A factory in China manufactures toys for use in connection with the sale of meals at a fast food restaurant. For a series of toys, a special plastic part is used that is produced very cheaply, but which also has a high probability of being defective, namely 30%. We wish to calculate the probability that, in a production of 1000 pieces, there are exactly between 675 and 725 (both numbers inclusive) functioning units.

english.context: Two girls, Elise and Sara, want to swim together. They have agreed to meet inside the swimming pool. It takes Elise ten minutes to change and Sara five minutes. Elise arrives at random between 11:50 and 12:10, Sara is a bit more imprecise and arrives at random between 11:40 and 12:20. It is also stated that they arrive independently of each other.
english.question: What is the probability that they meet in the changing room, given that Elise arrives first?

knowledge_points: Uniform distribution on a triangular region
explanation:
Let x be Elise’s arrival time (min from 12:00), x ∈ [-10,10], and y be Sara’s, y ∈ [-20,20], independent and uniform. Condition on Elise arriving first: y > x.
They meet in the changing room iff x < y < x + 10, but note that for x > 0 the band y < x + 10 is truncated by y ≤ 10 (Sara must arrive before 12:10 for the overlap to occur in the changing room after Elise’s post‑noon arrival).
Compute areas in the (x,y)-plane and take the ratio:
- Denominator A = {(x,y): -10 ≤ x ≤ 10, -20 ≤ y ≤ 20, y > x} has area ∫_{-10}^{10} (20 − x) dx = 400.
- Numerator B = {(x,y) ∈ A: y < min(x + 10, 10)} has area ∫_{-10}^{0} 10 dx + ∫_{0}^{10} (10 − x) dx = 150.
Thus P = area(B)/area(A) = 150/400 = 3/8.
explanation_key_steps: Model arrivals: x ∈ [-10,10], y ∈ [-20,20], independent uniforms.
Condition on Elise first: region y > x.
Compute areas of the favorable band and the conditioning region; take ratio.
explanation_pitfalls: Forgetting to condition on Elise arriving first (y > x).
Failing to truncate the band by y ≤ 10 for x > 0, which overcounts and leads to 1/2.

options: The pair (X, Y) is uncorrelated but not independent.

explanation: Uniform on the annulus centered at (1,1) with 1/2 ≤ (X−1)^2+(Y−1)^2 ≤ 1. Given E(X)=E(Y)=E(XY)=1, so Cov(X,Y)=E(XY)−E(X)E(Y)=1−1·1=0 ⇒ uncorrelated. Not independent: the marginals have support |x−1|<1 and |y−1|<1, so if X and Y were independent the joint would be positive on the entire square |x−1|<1, |y−1|<1, but the annulus assigns zero probability to the inner disk (x−1)^2+(y−1)^2<1/2. Contradiction.
explanation_key_steps: Show independence would imply positive joint density on the full product of marginal supports, which contradicts the hole in the annulus.
explanation_formulae: If independent: f_{X,Y}(x,y)=f_X(x)f_Y(y)>0 on the product of supports
explanation_pitfalls: Zero covariance does not imply independence.
Symmetry of the region does not make coordinates independent.
final_result_text: The pair (X, Y) is uncorrelated but not independent.

explanation:
Let X and Y be jointly normal with μX=150000, μY=250000, σX=25000, σY=35000, and ρ=−0.5. The sum S=X+Y is normal with mean μS=μX+μY=400000 and variance Var(S)=σX^2+σY^2+2ρσXσY.
Compute: σX^2=625e6, σY^2=1225e6, 2ρσXσY=2(−0.5)(25000)(35000)=−875e6. Hence Var(S)=625e6+1225e6−875e6=975e6, so σS=√975e6≈31225.
Standardize: Z=(450000−400000)/31225≈1.6006, so P(S>450000)=1−Φ(1.6006)≈0.055.

Compute covariance via ρσXσY and then Var(S)
Standardize threshold to Z and use standard normal tail

Treating X and Y as independent
